Pendleton High School Class of 2020 Graduation Ceremony

PHS will be conducting its graduation ceremony on Saturday, May 30th. Due to the pandemic impacts and social restrictions that are currently in place, this year’s ceremony will be different from year’s past, in particular, we will be utilizing a “drive-thru” strategy. Message from the Superintendent -- January 2020

Happy New Year!

There is much to be proud of in Pendleton and 2020 should be no exception. The Pendleton School District staff is poised to inspire and motivate students to excel in all aspects of their education. From the classroom to the athletic fields and from labs to field experiences, Pendleton students have access to a high-quality and diverse educational experience.

As we begin the new year, it is my hope that we challenge ourselves to inspire our students to excel, in order to make the Pendleton School District a continued source of community pride and one of the many reasons for families to live, learn, work and thrive in Eastern Oregon.

We are the Pendleton School District, and together we are committed to Every Student, Every Day.

Chris Fritsch
Superintendent

November is National Native American Heritage Month. This is a time to celebrate the diverse and rich culture, history and traditions of Native Americans. All Pendleton schools are organizing activities about our local Native American tribes.

Did you know that many of the foods we eat today were first cultivated by Native Americans, including potatoes, corn, peanuts, pumpkins, melons and sunflower seeds? Or that Native Americans were the first to practice conservation and ecology strategies? Please join us as we recognize the contributions of the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation in our area.To learn more, visit the CTUIR website: https://ctuir.org/

All Pendleton schools will be closed on Monday, November 11th in observance of Veterans Day.

Originally known as Armistice Day, the day was created to honor the veterans of World War I. In 1954, the day became Veterans Day to honor veterans of all wars.

Some people ask what the difference is between Veterans Day and Memorial Day. Memorial Day in May is when we honor those who have died in the line of duty. Veterans Day is a time to thank living veterans of all wars.

The Pendleton School District thanks all veterans for your sacrifice and service.

PHS music students recently performed at Disneyland. The Swing Choir, A Cappella Choir and the Jazz Ensemble included a total of 74 students, 15 chaperones and two directors. They performed on the Hollywood Backlot Stage in Disney’s California Adventure, which meant access backstage into restricted cast member areas and using Disney performers' dressing rooms and warm-up spaces.

In addition to performances, the students spent some free time in the park. The swing band ‘Phat Cat Swingers’, who perform high-energy swing band music in the park in several sets daily, invited the jazz band to visit with them following a set and have pictures taken with them.

"Our students left inspired and encouraged (and tired!). Each group earned a Disney Performing Arts plaque, and each student was recognized with a special Disney Performing Arts lanyard," said Emily Muller-Cary, PHS Choir Director.

As of 2 PM today, Mid Columbia Bus Company is short four drivers for the afternoon routes for Pendleton School District. Here are changes for after school today:
Lucky & Rocky – students will ride Rocky home tonight. We anticipate this will make the bus 15-30 minutes late towards the end of its run.
Snoopy will arrive 30 minutes late to pick up students and therefore will be 30 minutes later at drop-off sites.
Mickey – students who normally ride Mickey will be absorbed by the other special needs busses. Students will be loaded on busses that have the most similar route to Mickey. Students may be 30—45 minutes later than usual.
Snuffy will pick up and drop off approximately 30 minutes later than usual.

The Pendleton School District congratulates Rachelle Spicknall who was recently recognized as a finalist for Substitute Teacher of the Year by the Oregon Substitute Teachers Association (OSTA). Although Spicknall did not win the state award, she and all finalists will be recognized at the OSTA’s Annual Conference on October 20th in Salem.

Spicknall, who has been a substitute teacher in Pendleton for several years, said she was surprised and honored when Kelly Doherty, secretary at Sunridge Middle School, nominated her. "I love being a substitute teacher and building connections with students. I feel very fortunate to work in our schools -- Pendleton teachers are amazing and our students are incredible. I think we have great schools," Spicknall said.
